case_name: Appellants v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: 37 civil appeals before the Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The principal question of law which arises in this group of 37 civil appeals relates to the cons

facts.text: Two notified orders issued by State of Andhra Pradesh on 28th January 1955 and 30th January 1955

anchor.surface_text: The dispute which has given rise to these appeals centres round the validity of two notified orders issued by the respondent, State of Andhra Pradesh on the 28th January, 1955, and 30th January, 1955 respectively,

facts.text: Appellants supplied electricity by respondent for many years past

anchor.surface_text: and it is the contention of the appellants that the said notified orders are outside the purview of s. 3. The appellants in all these appeals are supplied electricity by the respondent for many years past,

facts.text: Individual agreements between appellants and respondent during 1946 to 1952 prescribing terms including rate for electricity supply

anchor.surface_text: and several individual agreements have been passed between them and the respondent during the period 1946 to 1952 prescribing the terms and conditions on which the said supply would be made to them. One of these terms stipulated the rate at which the supply of electricity had to be charged against the consumers.

facts.text: Impugned orders purported to increase the electricity rate stipulated in agreements

anchor.surface_text: The impugned orders have purported to increase this rate, and the appellants contend that the respondent had no authority to change this important term of the contract to their prejudice by taking recourse to s. 3(1) and issuing notified orders in that behalf.

facts.text: Government of Madras and successor had single power grid system comprising Tungabhadra and Machkund Hydro Electric System and Thermal System of Nellore

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Government of Madras, and subsequently, its successor, the respondent, had a single power grid system for the whole State comprising Tungabhadra and Machkund Hydro Electric System and the Thermal System of Nellore. The entire energy was integrated into one power system.

facts.text: Agreements with consumers including appellants for supply of energy in bulk at specified tariffs for 1951 and 1952, to operate for ten years

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madras entered into agreements with several consumers in the State, including the appellants, for the supply of energy in bulk at the specified rates which were called tariffs, for the years 1951 and 1952. These agreements were to be in operation for ten years.

facts.text: Agreements did not contain provision authorising Government to increase rates during operation, common ground

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that these agreements did not contain any provision authorising the Government to increase the rates during their operation.

facts.text: Charges fixed at graded regressive rates not to exceed 66 annas overall unit rates

anchor.surface_text: The charges fixed were calculated at graded regressive rates according to increasing slabs of consumption units, and the overall unit rates including the demand charge were not to exceed 66 annas without prejudice to the monthly minimum payment and the guaranteed consumption.

facts.text: Impugned orders enhanced agreed rates for Machkund and Nellore, and Tungabhadra and Chittoor District areas

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Andhra then issued the two impugned orders relating to Machkund and Nellore, and Tungabhadra and Chittoor District areas respectively, enhancing the agreed rates. These enhanced rates were specified in Schedules A and B attached to the said orders.

facts.text: Increased tariffs to take effect from meter readings in February 1955, prospectively

anchor.surface_text: According to these orders, these increased tariffs were to take effect from the date on which meter readings were to be taken in the month of February, 1955 and were to operate for the future. The increase in the rates effected by these orders was thus to operate not retrospectively, but prospectively.

facts.text: Reason for orders: existing tariffs formulated 15 years before, uneconomic due to increased labour and material costs, growing losses

anchor.surface_text: The impugned orders indicate that the main reason which inspired the said orders was the knowledge that the existing electricity tariffs which were formulated nearly 15 years before, had become completely uneconomic the charges of labour and the price level of all material had enormously increased and that inevitably meant continuously growing loss to the Government.

facts.text: Accountant-General queried recurring losses and drew attention to deficits

anchor.surface_text: The Accountant-General made queries in respect of this recurring loss and drew pointed attention of the State Government to the deficits in the working of the Power System.

facts.text: Revision of tariffs considered in Madras but not decided due to States reorganization

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the question of revision of tariffs was considered in the State of Madras, but was not decided because reorganisation of the States was then in contemplation.

facts.text: After Andhra Pradesh State formed, Chief Engineer submitted proposals for tariff revisions

anchor.surface_text: After the respondent State was born, its Chief Engineer submitted proposals for revisions of tariffs in all the areas covered by the relevant schemes. That is how the impugned notified orders came to be issued by the respondent.

facts.text: Consumers moved Andhra Pradesh High Court under Art 226 challenging validity of orders

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, a large number of consumers moved the Andhra Pradesh High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution, and challenged the validity of the two impugned orders.

facts.text: Single Judge upheld appellants' plea, held orders unauthorised, allowed writ petitions

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge who heard these writ petitions upheld the appellants plea and came to the conclusion that the impugned orders were not justified by the authority conferred on the respondent by s. 3 of the Act, and were unauthorised, illegal and inoperative.

facts.text: Division Bench allowed Letters Patent Appeals by respondent, dismissed writ petitions

anchor.surface_text: These decisions were challenged by the respondent by preferring several Letters Patent Appeals. The Division Bench which heard these Letters Patent Appeals took a different view it held that on its fair and reasonable construction, s. 3 did confer authority on the respondent to issue the impugned orders,

facts.text: Appeals to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court, and some by special leave

anchor.surface_text: It is against these orders that the appellants have come to this Court with a certificate issued by the said High Court. After the Division Bench had pronounced its decision on this point, several other writ petitions were filed by other consumers,

facts.text: Madras Essential Articles Control and Requisitioning Temporary Powers Act, 1949 No. 29 of 1949

anchor.surface_text: The principal question of law which arises in this group of 37 civil appeals relates to the construction of section 3 of the Madras Essential Articles Control and Requisitioning Temporary Powers Act, 1949 No. 29 of 1949 hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh Act No. 1 of 1955 assented by President on 21st January 1955, adopted Madras Act

anchor.surface_text: After the respondent State was created under the Scheme of Reorganisation of States, it passed Act No. 1 of 1955 and this Act received the assent of the President on the 21st of January, 1955. By this Act, the Legislature of the respondent State virtually adopted the Madras Act.

facts.text: Electrical energy listed as essential article in Schedule under Andhra Act

anchor.surface_text: When the Andhra Legislature passed Act No. 1 of 1955 and adopted the Schedule of essential articles for its purpose, the number of these articles was reduced to two they are charcoal and electrical energy.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 25, 1964 by Gajendragadkar C.J.

anchor.surface_text: March 25, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C. J.-The principal question of law which arises in this group of 37 civil appeals relates to the cons

facts.text: Appeals from judgments dated December 19, 1958, March 7, 1959 etc. in Writ Appeals Nos. 135, 122 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 429 439, 591, 592, 597, 689, 694, 724, 725 and 727 of 1962 and 15, 139, 140, 159, 267 to 269, 331, 334, 337, 340, 342, 343, 347, 352, 389, 746 and 748 of 1963. Appeals from the judg- ments and order dated December 19, 1958, March 7, 1959,

The principal question of law which arises in this group of 37 civil appeals relates to the construction of section 3 of the Madras Essential Articles Control and Requisitioning Temporary Powers Act, 1949 No. 29 of 1949 hereinafter called the Act .

concepts.interpretation: Empowers State Govt to issue notified orders regulating supply, distribution, transport of essential articles including electricity, even when supplied by State itself, allowing modification of contractual rates prospectively to ensure fair prices and continued supply.

anchor.surface_text: Before addressing ourselves to the question of construing s. 3, it is necessary to recapitulate the legislative history of the Act. It will be recalled that during the Second World War, the Government of India passed the Defence of India Act No. 35 of 1939

issues.text: The principal question of law which arises in this group of 37 civil appeals relates to the construction of section 3 of the Madras Essential Articles Control and Requisitioning Temporary Powers Act, 1949 (No. 29 of 1949) and whether the impugned notified orders are within the purview of s.3.

anchor.surface_text: The principal question of law which arises in this group of 37 civil appeals relates to the construction of section 3 of the Madras Essential Articles Control and Requisitioning Temporary Powers Act, 1949 No. 29 of 1949 hereinafter called the Act . The dispute which has given rise to these appeals centres round the validity of two notified orders issued by the respondent, State of Andhra Pradesh on the 28th January, 1955, and 30th January, 1955 respectively, and it is the contention of the appellants that the said notified orders are outside the purview of s. 3.

issues.text: Whether the State Government would be bound by the provisions of legislative enactments passed by the State Legislature, particularly in the context of s.3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the State Government would be bound by the provisions of legislative enactments passed by the State Legislature has sometimes led to difference in judicial opinion but the decision of this Court in the Director of Rationing

issues.text: Whether the impugned notified orders are invalid because they contravene the provisions of Art. 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the next question as to whether the impugned notified orders are invalid, because they contravene the provisions of Art. 19 1 f and g of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the impugned orders contravene Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad also attempted to challenge the validity of the impugned orders on the ground that they contravene Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the power to regulate under s.3(1) includes the power to increase tariff rates or is limited to reducing rates.
Whether the clauses in s.3(2) limit the generality of powers under s.3(1).

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the State Government would be bound by the provisions of legislative enactments passed by the State Legislature has sometimes led to difference in judicial opinion but the decision of this Court in the Director of Rationing

arguments.claim: s.3(1) words wide enough to include regulation of State's own supply of essential articles

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1  is obviously intended to secure supplies of essential articles and to arrange for their equitable distribution and availability at fair prices. If electrical energy is one of the essential articles mentioned in the Schedule, there can be no difficulty in holding that a notified order can be issued under s. 3 1  for regulating the supply of the said energy and making it available at a fair price.

arguments.claim: s.3(2) clauses are merely illustrative and do not limit s.3(1)

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of the Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee 1 , it is well-settled that the function of a clause like clause  2  of s. 3 merely illustrative  vide also Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State 3  .

arguments.claim: Impugned orders reasonable under Art.19 as they ensure continued supply and prevent public loss

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, having regard to all the circumstances in this case, we are disposed to hold that the change made in the tariff by the notified orders must be held to be reasonable and in the interests of the general public.

arguments.claim: No violation of Art.14 due to lack of specific allegations of discrimination

holdings.text: The challenge to the validity of the impugned notified orders on the ground that they are outside the purview of s. 3(1) cannot be sustained.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of s.3(1) are clear, wide, and unambiguous, empowering regulation of supply including by State itself for equitable distribution at fair prices; cannot be limited by scheme or s.3(2) illustrative clauses.

holdings.text: The State is not bound by a statute unless provided in express terms or by necessary implication.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the State Government would be bound by the provisions of legislative enactments passed by the State Legislature has sometimes led to difference in judicial opinion but the decision of this Court in the Director of Rationing

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents like Director of Rationing v. Corporation of Calcutta and Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corp; rule applies even when State claims benefit.

holdings.text: s.3(2) clauses are merely illustrative and do not limit the generality of powers under s.3(1).

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of the Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee 1 , it is well-settled that the function of a clause like clause  2  of s. 3 merely illustrative  vide also Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State 3  .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per settled law from Sibnath Banerjee and Santosh Kumar Jain; specific clauses do not cut down general words.

holdings.text: The power to regulate under s.3(1) includes the power to increase tariff rates.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Regulate' is wide enough to include increase or decrease based on economic factors to ensure fair prices.

holdings.text: The impugned notified orders do not contravene Art.19(1)(f) and (g); the change in tariff is reasonable and in the interests of the general public.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, having regard to all the circumstances in this case, we are disposed to hold that the change made in the tariff by the numberified orders must be held to be reasonable and in the interests of the general public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders prevent losses, ensure continued supply to community; prospective, no claim of excessiveness; public interest outweighs contractual rights.

holdings.text: The impugned orders do not contravene Art.14 as there is no material showing irrational discrimination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of specific pleadings and evidence of discrimination without rational nexus; vague allegations insufficient.

precedents.citation: Director of Rationing and Distribution v. The Corporation of Calcutta and Ors.  1  1961 1 S.C.R. 158

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in the Director of Rationing and Distribution v. The Corporation of Calcutta and Ors.  1  must be taken to have settled this question. The effect of the majority decision rendered in that case is to recognise the validity of the rule of interpretation of statutes enunciated by the Privy Council in Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay  2  and that rule is that the State is number bound by a statute unless it is so provided in express terms or by necessary implication.

precedents.case_name: Director of Rationing and Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: State is not bound by a statute unless provided in express terms or by necessary implication

precedents.citation: Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay  2 73 I.A. 271

anchor.surface_text: enunciated by the Privy Council in Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay  2  and that rule is that the State is number bound by a statute unless it is so provided in express terms or by necessary implication. In applying this rule, it is obviously necessary that the Court must attempt to ascertain the intention of the Legislature by companysidernig all the relevant provisions of the statute together and number companycentrating its attention on a particular provision which may be in dispute between the parties.

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: State is not bound by a statute unless provided in express terms or by necessary implication

anchor.surface_text: Province of Bomboy 1  and it still companytinues to be a law in this Country. Incidentally, we may add that where the Crown seeks to take advantage of a statute and urges that though it is number bound by the statute, it is at liberty to take advantage of it, English Law does number easily entertain such a plea, though there are observations made in some judicial pronouncements to the companytrary.

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: State may claim benefit of statute under same rule of construction

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee 1 72 I.A. 241 at p. 248

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of the Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee 1 , it is well-settled that the function of a clause like clause  2  of s. 3 merely illustrative  vide also Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State 3  . In other words, the proper approach to adopt in companystruing clauses  1  and  2  of s. 3 is to assume that whatever is included in clause  2  is also included in clause  1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: function of a general clause like sub-section (2) is merely illustrative of powers in sub-section (1)

precedents.citation: Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State 3 1951 S.C.R. 303

anchor.surface_text: merely illustrative  vide also Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State 3  . In other words, the proper approach to adopt in companystruing clauses  1  and  2  of s. 3 is to assume that whatever is included in clause  2  is also included in clause  1 . That is number to say that if the words of clause  1  are wide enough to include cases number included in clause  2 , they must, for that reason, receive a narrower companystruction.

precedents.case_name: Santosh Kumar Jain v. The State
precedents.cited_proposition: function of a general clause like sub-section (2) is merely illustrative of powers in sub-section (1)
